title: What percent of peasants were land owning? - Quora

response.answer_text: With the usual caveats about the Middle Ages lasting a thousand years and the term referring to entities as different as Iceland and Sicily, the Hansa Cities and the Italian Communes: None. In feudal societies there was no capitalist concept of land ownership at all. Barons, lords and knights did not own the land either. They held it in fief from the king. Renowned French historian Regine Pernoud points out in her book Those Terrible Middle Ages: Debunking the Myths (Ignatius, 1977, p.88): It was this intimate connection between man and the soil on which he lived that constituted serfdom, for, in all other respects, the serf had all the rights of a free man: he could marry, establish a family, his land, as well as the goods he was able to acquire, would pass to his children at his death. The lord, let us note, had, although on a totally different scale, the same obligations as the serf, for he could neither sell nor give up his land nor desert it. If your question is about the average size of a peasant holding, that depends entirely on the region (Iceland? Poland? Sicily? Hungary? Cyprus? Aragon?) and the period (what part of that one thousand years of history we call the Middle Ages) you are talking about.

During most of the feudal period, none. They were under a villeinage obligation to their baron for land to work, for which they had to furnish both crops and labor to the castle. Freeholding began in the last centuries of the feudal period, when they began to desert their lords and go into unclaimed waste lands and the new “free cities’’ which began by depending on each other for crops and goods-and-services in a new currency economy. The law then offered such freedom legally to any serf-escapee who had maintained his independence “for a year and a day” . Martin Harris

Where? When? In France in 1850? This question is too broad. Some have answered assuming it refers to mediaeval Europe, but there’s nothing in the question to say that. The answer could be, depending on time & place, anything from zero to 100%.
